Title: Does Java have a ternary conditional operator? Body:

Is there a ternary conditional operator in Java?

Title: What are Class objects in Java? Body:

What are java.lang.Class objects? What are they used for?

Title: How do I check whether a file exists without exceptions? Body:

How do I check whether a file exists or not in Java, without using a try/catch block?

Title: How do I execute a program or call a system command? Body:

How do I call an external command within Java as if I had typed it in a shell or command prompt?

Title: How do I create a directory, and any missing parent directories? Body:

How do I create a directory at a given path in Java, and also create any missing parent directories along that path? For example, the Bash command mkdir -p /path/to/nested/directory does this.

Title: How do I make a flat list out of a list of lists? Body:

I have a list of lists like

[
    [1, 2, 3],
    [4, 5, 6],
    [7],
    [8, 9]
]

How can I flatten it to get [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9] in Java?

If your list of lists comes from a nested loop or stream pipeline, the problem can be solved more simply/directly by fixing that construction.

The most popular solutions here generally only flatten one "level" of the nested list. See discussions about flattening irregular (arbitrarily nested) lists for solutions that completely flatten a deeply nested structure (recursively, in general).

Title: What is the difference between static methods and instance methods in Java? Body:

What is the difference between a static method and an instance method in Java? When should each be used, and how do they differ in terms of access to instance state and inheritance?

Title: How slicing in Java works. Body:

How does Java's subrange indexing work? That is: when I write code like list.subList(x, y), list.subList(0, list.size()), string.substring(x, y), or Arrays.copyOfRange(array, x, y), how can I understand which elements end up in the slice or view?

See explanations of why Java's upper bounds are exclusive (e.g., why list.subList(0, 2) contains elements at indexes 0 and 1, not 2).
See approaches for taking every Nth element from a list using IntStream.range and filtering by index.
See how assignment or mutation works on a List.subList view (e.g., how changes to the sublist reflect in the original list).

Title: How to find the index for a given item in a list?. Body:

Given a list ["foo", "bar", "baz"] and an item in the list "bar", how do I get its index 1?

Title: How to use a static variable in a method? Body:

How do I create or use a static (class-level) variable inside a method?

How do I use a static variable that was defined in one method inside other methods?

Title: How do I get the current time in Java? Body:

How do I get the current time in Java?

Title: How to copy files. Body:

How do I copy a file in Java?

Title: How can I remove a specific item from a List in Java? Body:

How do I remove a specific value from a list? Something like:

list.remove(value);

Constraints: I have to use core Java. Frameworks are not allowed.

Title: Loop (for-each) over an array in Java Body:

How can I loop through all the entries in an array using Java?

Title: How to insert an item into an array at a specific index? Body:

I am looking for a Java array insert method, in the style of:

arr.insert(index, item)

Preferably using the Java standard library, but any Java implementation will do at this point.

Title: Checking if a key exists in a Java Map or JSONObject? Body:

How do I check if a particular key exists in a Java Map or a JSONObject?

If a key doesn't exist and I try to access it, will it return null or throw an exception?

Title: How can I check if an object is an array? Body:

I'm trying to write a method that either accepts a list of strings, or a single string. If it's a string, then I want to convert it to an array with just the one item so I can loop over it without fear of an error.

So how do I check if the variable is an array?

Title: Deleting an element from an array in Java Body:

Is there an easy way to delete an element from an array in Java, such that iterating over it (e.g., with a for loop or enhanced for) no longer includes that element?

I thought that setting it to null would do it, but it apparently does not work.

Title: How to append something to an array? Body:

How do I append an object (such as a string or number) to an array in Java?

Title: How do I determine whether an array contains a particular value in Java?. Body:

I have a String[] with values like so:

public static final String[] VALUES = new String[] {"AB","BC","CD","AE"};

Given String s, is there a good way of testing whether VALUES contains s?

Title: How do I declare and initialize an array in Java?. Body:

How do I declare and initialize an array in Java?

Title: Remove duplicate values from Java List Body:

I have a very simple Java list that may or may not contain duplicates.

List<String> names = Arrays.asList("Mike","Matt","Nancy","Adam","Jenny","Nancy","Carl");

I need to remove the duplicates and put the unique values in a new list.

I could point to all the code that I've tried but I think it's useless because they don't work. I accept solutions using Java standard libraries too.

Similar question:

  • Get all non-unique values (i.e.: duplicate/more than one occurrence) in an array

Title: How do I empty a List in Java? Body:

Is there a way to empty a List and if so possibly with a remove() method?

For instance,

List<Integer> A = Arrays.asList(1, 2, 3, 4);

How can I empty that?

Title: What is the difference between @Column(nullable = true) and @NotBlank/@NotNull in JPA? Body:

When I add a field to a JPA entity I usually write:

@Column(length = 100, nullable = true)
private String name;

Similar things are done with relationships and other types. What is the basic difference between:

  1. @Column(nullable = true) only
  2. @NotBlank/@NotNull only (Bean Validation)
  3. Using both @Column(nullable = true) and @NotBlank/@NotNull

How does this apply to different fields such as String, @ManyToOne, @ManyToMany, and LocalDateTime? What are the advantages/disadvantages of using option 1, 2, or 3?

Title: Has Spring Boot served an excess of 100k daily visits? Body:

I'm building a web application with Spring Boot. The reasons I chose Spring Boot were:

  • I wanted to work with free/open-source tools.
  • I like Java and feel it's a long-term language, whereas regarding Ruby I wasn't sure, and PHP seemed like a huge hassle to learn.
  • I'm building a prototype for an idea and wasn't thinking too much about the future. Development speed was the main factor, and I already knew Java.
  • I knew the migration to Google App Engine would be easier should I choose to do so in the future.
  • I heard Spring Boot was "nice".

Now that I'm getting closer to thinking about publishing my work, I start being concerned about scale. The only information I found about the scaling capabilities of Spring Boot is provided by the Spring team (I'm not saying anything to disregard them, but this is clearly not objective information...).

Has an independent development team reported building a Spring Boot–based site that reliably handles an excess of 100k daily visits?

Title: Is there a list of pytz timezones? Body:

I would like to know all possible values for the timezone argument in a Java time zone library. How can I list them?

Title: How do I do a not equal in JPA Criteria filtering? Body:

In JPA Criteria queries I can use comparisons like greaterThan and lessThan, but is there a direct not equals condition? I want to filter out using a not equals. For example, for

Entity:
    boolean a;
    int x;

I want to do something like

// exclude where a is true and x != 5

I tried a few approaches but didn't find a clean not-equals filter. I ended up doing:

criteria.where(
    cb.or(
        cb.notEqual(root.get("a"), true),
        cb.equal(root.get("x"), 5)
    )
);

Is there a more direct way to express “a is true and x is not 5” in JPA Criteria?

Title: How to revert the last Flyway migration? Body:

I ran a Flyway migration that added a new table and want to roll it back and remove the migration, without creating a new migration.

How do I do it? Is there a command to undo the last migration so I can delete the migration file?

Title: What is a "slug" in a Java web application?
Body: When I read Java web app code I often see references to a "slug" in models or URL mappings. I’m not quite sure what this is, but I do know it has something to do with URLs. How and when is this slug supposed to be used? I’ve seen it described as a short label containing only letters, numbers, underscores, or hyphens, generally used in URLs—for example, in a blog entry URL, the last path segment (like “spring”) is the slug.

Title: Where does Maven install its dependencies? Body:

I activated a Java project environment and used Maven to add a dependency:

mvn dependency:get -Dartifact=org.springframework:spring-context:5.3.0

The dependency downloaded successfully. Now I want to open up the JAR folder. Where is it located?

Normally I’d expect it in a “downloads” folder, but I’m not sure where Maven stores dependencies when I download them this way.

Title: How to upload a file in Spring MVC? Body:

What is the minimal example code needed for a "hello world" app using Spring MVC, that enables the user to upload a file?

Title: How to check Java framework version Body:

I have to use Java and a web framework for our application. I have two JDKs installed, 8 and 11. I’ve installed the framework and can run a sample application successfully. How do I check which JDK version the framework is using and what versions of its modules it uses?

Title: How to debug in Spring Boot, the good way? Body:

So, I started learning to code in Java and later Spring Boot. The first times it was hard looking at stack traces and actually figure out what I did wrong and where the syntax error was. Some time has passed now and some way along the way, I guess I got a routine in debugging my Spring Boot code. As this was done early in my coding experience, I sat down and wondered if how I was doing this was ineffective and could be done faster. I usually manage to find and correct the bugs in my code, but I wonder if I should be doing it faster?

I usually just use the debug info Spring Boot gives when enabled. When things do end up as I thought it would, I break the code flow a lot with a syntax error, and look at the variables at that point in the flow to figure out, where the code does something other than what I wanted.

But can this be improved? Are there some good tools or better ways to debug your Spring Boot code?

Title: How can I upgrade specific dependencies using Maven and a pom.xml? Body:

I'm using Maven with a pom.xml for my Spring projects. I'm trying to upgrade some dependencies, notably Spring itself, and I'm getting an error about source code conflicts:

Source in <local Maven repo>/org/springframework/spring-context has version 5.3.20 that conflicts with spring-context==5.3.21 (from pom.xml)

That's after updating the version number of Spring from 5.3.20 to 5.3.21 in my pom.xml. I'm using this command to actually do the upgrade:

mvn -U clean install -f <path to pom.xml>

I can't find any flag that forces a full dependency re-download. I even tried deleting the dependency and rebuilding, but no dice. Am I missing something?

Title: How to reset Spring Security admin password? Body:

I am using a Java web app with Spring Security and have forgotten both the admin username and password. How do I reset both?

Is it possible to grant a regular user admin privileges and later revoke them?

Title: How to get query parameters in a Java HttpServletRequest? Body:

I am defining URL patterns and want to capture parameters from the URL. How do I access query parameters from the URL as part of the HttpServletRequest object?

Right now, calling request.getParameterMap() returns an empty map.

I’d like to learn how to do this without a library, so I can get to know the Servlet API better.

Title: How to filter empty or NULL names in a JPA query? Body:

I have firstName, lastName & alias (optional) which I need to search for. So, I need a query to give me all the names that have an alias set.

Only if I could do:

// pseudo-code
nameRepository.filter(alias != "")

So, what is the equivalent to the above in Java (JPA/JPQL or Criteria API)?

Title: NoClassDefFoundError: org/apache/commons/lang3/StringUtils Body:

I'm deploying a Spring MVC app to a dev server and am hitting this error when I run mvn clean install:

Exception in thread "main" java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/apache/commons/lang3/StringUtils
    at com.example.myapp.util.TextUtil.<clinit>(TextUtil.java:12)
    at com.example.myapp.Main.main(Main.java:8)
Caused by: java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: org.apache.commons.lang3.StringUtils
    at java.base/jdk.internal.loader.BuiltinClassLoader.loadClass(BuiltinClassLoader.java:641)
    at java.base/jdk.internal.loader.ClassLoaders$AppClassLoader.loadClass(ClassLoaders.java:188)
    at java.base/java.lang.ClassLoader.loadClass(ClassLoader.java:526)
    ... 2 more

StringUtils is part of org.apache.commons:commons-lang3. Initially I thought this dependency might not be on the classpath in the dev environment, so I added it to my pom.xml:

<dependency>
  <groupId>org.apache.commons</groupId>
  <artifactId>commons-lang3</artifactId>
  <version>3.12.0</version>
</dependency>

EDIT: This only happens on the dev server. If I run the app locally then the class is found, but I still get the same error on the server.

Any ideas as to why commons-lang3 isn't on the classpath?

Title: How to iterate over rows in a Tablesaw Table? Body:

I have a Tablesaw table, table:

   c1   c2
0  10  100
1  11  110
2  12  120

How do I iterate over the rows of this table? For every row, I want to access its elements (values in cells) by the name of the columns. For example:

for (Row row : table) {
    System.out.println(row.getInt("c1") + " " + row.getInt("c2"));
}

I found a similar question that suggests using different iteration styles in Tablesaw, but I do not understand what the Row object is and how I can work with it.

Title: How do I select rows from a Tablesaw Table based on column values? Body:

How can I select rows from a Tablesaw Table based on values in a column?

In SQL, I would use:

SELECT *
FROM table
WHERE column_name = some_value

How do I change the size of a chart drawn with JFreeChart?

I want to change the column labels of a Java DataFrame from

['$a', '$b', '$c', '$d', '$e']

to

['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e']

Title: Delete a column from a Tablesaw Table. Body:

To delete a column in a Tablesaw Table, I can successfully use:

table.removeColumns("column_name");

But why can’t I use the following?

table.column_name;

Since it’s possible to access a column via table.column("column_name"), I expected a direct table.column_name form to work for deletion as well.

Title: How do I get the row count of a Tablesaw Table? Body:

How do I get the number of rows of a Tablesaw Table named table?

Title: Selecting multiple columns in a Tablesaw DataFrame Body:

How do I select columns a and b from a Tablesaw Table named df, and save them into a new Table df1?

index  a   b   c
1      2   3   4
2      3   4   5

Unsuccessful attempt:

Table df1 = df.select("a":"b");

Title: How to change the order of Tablesaw Table columns? Body:

I have the following Tablesaw Table:

import tech.tablesaw.api.DoubleColumn;
import tech.tablesaw.api.Table;

Table df = Table.create("df")
        .addColumns(
                DoubleColumn.create("c0", DoubleColumn.of("c0", /* 10 random values */)),
                DoubleColumn.create("c1", DoubleColumn.of("c1", /* 10 random values */)),
                DoubleColumn.create("c2", DoubleColumn.of("c2", /* 10 random values */)),
                DoubleColumn.create("c3", DoubleColumn.of("c3", /* 10 random values */)),
                DoubleColumn.create("c4", DoubleColumn.of("c4", /* 10 random values */))
        );

I add more column(s) by assignment:

df.addColumns(DoubleColumn.create("mean", /* row-wise mean values */));

How can I move the column mean to the front, i.e. set it as the first column while leaving the order of the other columns untouched?

Title: Change column type in Tablesaw. Body:

I created a Table from a list of lists:

List<List<String>> table = List.of(
    List.of("a", "1.2", "4.2"),
    List.of("b", "70",  "0.03"),
    List.of("x", "5",   "0")
);

How do I convert the columns to specific types? In this case, I want to convert columns 2 and 3 into floats (e.g., double columns).

Is there a way to specify the types while converting the list to a Table? Or is it better to create the Table first and then loop through the columns to change the column type for each column? Ideally I would like to do this in a dynamic way because there can be hundreds of columns, and I don't want to specify exactly which columns are of which type. All I can guarantee is that each column contains values of the same type.

Title: How to drop rows in a Tablesaw Table where a column is missing (NaN) Body:

I have this Tablesaw Table and want only the rows where the EPS column is not missing/NaN:

                 STK_ID  EPS  cash
STK_ID RPT_Date                   
601166 20111231  601166  NaN   NaN
600036 20111231  600036  NaN    12
600016 20111231  600016  4.3   NaN
601009 20111231  601009  NaN   NaN
601939 20111231  601939  2.5   NaN
000001 20111231  000001  NaN   NaN

...i.e., I want a result like:

                  STK_ID  EPS  cash
STK_ID RPT_Date                   
600016 20111231  600016  4.3   NaN
601939 20111231  601939  2.5   NaN

How do I do that in Tablesaw?

Title: Get a list of column headers from a Tablesaw Table Body:

I want to get a list of the column headers from a Tablesaw Table. The table will come from user input, so I won’t know how many columns there will be or what they will be called.

For example, if I’m given a table like this:

    y  gdp  cap
0   1    2    5
1   2    3    9
2   8    7    2
3   3    4    7
4   6    7    7
5   4    8    3
6   8    2    8
7   9    9   10
8   6    6    4
9  10   10    7

I would get a list like this:

["y", "gdp", "cap"]

Title: Use a list of values to select rows from a Tablesaw Table Body:

Let’s say I have the following Tablesaw table:

import tech.tablesaw.api.Table;
import tech.tablesaw.api.IntColumn;

Table t = Table.create("t")
    .addColumns(
        IntColumn.create("A", new int[] {5, 6, 3, 4}),
        IntColumn.create("B", new int[] {1, 2, 3, 5})
    );
System.out.println(t);

   |  A |  B |
   |----|----|
 0 |  5 |  1 |
 1 |  6 |  2 |
 2 |  3 |  3 |
 3 |  4 |  5 |

I can subset based on a specific value:

Table x = t.where(t.intColumn("A").isEqualTo(3));
System.out.println(x);

   |  A |  B |
   |----|----|
 2 |  3 |  3 |

But how can I subset based on a list of values? Something like:

List<Integer> listOfValues = Arrays.asList(3, 6);

Table y = t.where(t.intColumn("A").isIn(listOfValues));

To get:

   |  A |  B |
   |----|----|
 1 |  6 |  2 |
 2 |  3 |  3 |

Title: How to add a new column to an existing Tablesaw Table Body:

I have the following Table (Tablesaw) with named columns and row labels that are not continuous:

Table t = Table.create("data")
    .addColumns(
        DoubleColumn.create("a", new double[]{0.671399, 0.446172, 0.614758}),
        DoubleColumn.create("b", new double[]{0.101208, -0.243316, 0.075793}),
        DoubleColumn.create("c", new double[]{-0.181532, 0.051767, -0.451460}),
        DoubleColumn.create("d", new double[]{0.241273, 1.577318, -0.012493})
    );

I want to add a new column e to the existing table without changing anything else (the new column always has the same length as the table):

double[] e = new double[]{-0.335485, -1.166658, -0.385571};

How can I add column e to the table?

Title: Pretty-print an entire Tablesaw Table / Column Body:

I work with Tablesaw Table and columns in the terminal a lot. The default string representation shows a reduced sample with head and tail values, but the rest is missing.

Is there a built-in way to pretty-print the entire Table (or a column) in Java? Ideally, it would support proper alignment, borders between columns, and maybe even color-coding for different columns.

Title: “Large data” workflows using Java (out-of-core) Body:

I have tried to puzzle out an answer to this question for many months while learning Java data tools. I use SAS for my day-to-day work and it is great for its out-of-core support. However, SAS is horrible as a piece of software for numerous other reasons.

One day I hope to replace my use of SAS with Java, but I currently lack an out-of-core workflow for large datasets. I'm not talking about "big data" that requires a distributed network, but rather files too large to fit in memory but small enough to fit on a hard-drive.

My first thought is to use an on-disk store like HDF5 (via a Java HDF5 library) or a local database (SQLite, H2, or DuckDB) to hold large datasets on disk and pull only the pieces I need into Java data structures for analysis. My question is this:

What are some best-practice workflows for accomplishing the following:

  1. Loading flat files into a permanent, on-disk database structure
  2. Querying that database to retrieve data to feed into an in-memory Java data structure (e.g., Tablesaw Table or similar)
  3. Updating the database after manipulating pieces in Java

Real-world examples would be much appreciated, especially from anyone who uses Java on "large data".

Edit -- an example of how I would like this to work:

  1. Iteratively import a large flat-file and store it in a permanent, on-disk database structure. These files are typically too large to fit in memory.
  2. In order to use in-memory analysis, I would like to read subsets of this data (usually just a few columns at a time) that can fit in memory.
  3. I would create new columns by performing various operations on the selected columns.
  4. I would then have to append these new columns into the database structure.

I am trying to find a best-practice way of performing these steps. Reading links about Java data tools and HDF5 it seems that appending a new column could be a problem.

Edit -- Responding to questions specifically:

  1. I am building consumer credit risk models. The kinds of data include phone, SSN and address characteristics; property values; derogatory information like criminal records, bankruptcies, etc... The datasets I use every day have nearly 1,000 to 2,000 fields on average of mixed data types: continuous, nominal and ordinal variables of both numeric and character data. I rarely append rows, but I do perform many operations that create new columns.
  2. Typical operations involve combining several columns using conditional logic into a new, compound column. For example, if var1 > 2 then newvar = "A" else if var2 == 4 then newvar = "B". The result of these operations is a new column for every record in my dataset.
  3. Finally, I would like to append these new columns into the on-disk data structure. I would repeat step 2, exploring the data with crosstabs and descriptive statistics trying to find interesting, intuitive relationships to model.
  4. A typical project file is usually about 1GB. Files are organized into such a manner where a row consists of a record of consumer data. Each row has the same number of columns for every record. This will always be the case.
  5. It's pretty rare that I would subset by rows when creating a new column. However, it's pretty common for me to subset on rows when creating reports or generating descriptive statistics. For example, I might want to create a simple frequency for a specific line of business, say Retail credit cards. To do this, I would select only those records where the line of business = retail in addition to whichever columns I want to report on. When creating new columns, however, I would pull all rows of data and only the columns I need for the operations.
  6. The modeling process requires that I analyze every column, look for interesting relationships with some outcome variable, and create new compound columns that describe those relationships. The columns that I explore are usually done in small sets. For example, I will focus on a set of say 20 columns just dealing with property values and observe how they relate to defaulting on a loan. Once those are explored and new columns are created, I then move on to another group of columns, say college education, and repeat the process. What I'm doing is creating candidate variables that explain the relationship between my data and some outcome. At the very end of this process, I apply some learning techniques that create an equation out of those compound columns.

It is rare that I would ever add rows to the dataset. I will nearly always be creating new columns (variables or features in statistics/machine learning parlance).

Title: Writing a Tablesaw Table to CSV file. Body:

I have a data frame in Java (Tablesaw) which I would like to write to a CSV file.

I am doing this using:

table.write().csv("out.csv");

And getting a Unicode encoding error when the data contains characters like α.

  • Is there any way to get around this easily (i.e. I have Unicode characters in my data frame)?
  • And is there a way to write to a tab-delimited file instead of a CSV using something like a “to-tab” method?

Title: How to check whether a string contains a substring in Java? Body:

Usually I would expect a String.contains() method, but I’m not sure what the best approach is in Java.

What is a reasonable way to check for this?

Title: How do I replace all occurrences of a substring in Java? Body:

Given a string:

String s = "Test abc test test abc test test test abc test test abc";

This seems to only remove the first occurrence of abc in the string above:

s = s.replaceFirst("abc", "");

How do I replace all occurrences of it?

Title: How do I make the first letter of a string uppercase in Java? Body:

How do I make the first character of a string uppercase if it's a letter, but not change the case of any of the other letters?

For example:

  • "this is a test" → "This is a test"
  • "the Eiffel Tower" → "The Eiffel Tower"
  • "/index.html" → "/index.html"

Title: Why is char[] preferred over String for passwords?. Body:

In Swing, the password field has a getPassword() (returns char[]) method instead of the usual getText() (returns String) method. Similarly, I have come across a suggestion not to use String to handle passwords.

Why does String pose a threat to security when it comes to passwords? It feels inconvenient to use char[].

Title: Convert bytes to a string in Java Body:

I captured the standard output of an external program into a byte[]:

Process p = new ProcessBuilder("ls", "-l").redirectErrorStream(true).start();
byte[] stdout = p.getInputStream().readAllBytes();
System.out.println(Arrays.toString(stdout));

I want to convert that to a normal Java String, so that I can print it like this:

System.out.print(stdoutAsString);
-rw-rw-r-- 1 thomas thomas 0 Mar  3 07:03 file1
-rw-rw-r-- 1 thomas thomas 0 Mar  3 07:03 file2

How do I convert the byte[] to a String in Java?

See the related question on converting a String to byte[] for the other way around.

Title: How do I convert a String to an int in Java?. Body:

How can I convert a String value to an int type?

"1234"  →  1234

Title: Creating multiline strings in Java. Body:

I have the following code in Ruby. I want to convert this code into Java. What is the equivalent code in Java?

text = <<"HERE"
This
Is
A
Multiline
String
HERE

Title: Case-insensitive `contains(String)` in Java Body:

Is there a way to make the following return true?

String title = "ASTRINGTOTEST";
title.contains("string");

There doesn't seem to be an overload that lets me set case sensitivity. Currently I UPPERCASE them both, but that's just silly (by which I am referring to the i18n issues that come with up- and down casing).

UPDATE

This question is ancient and since then I have realized I asked for a simple answer for a really vast and difficult topic if you care to investigate it fully.

For most cases, in mono-lingual, English code bases this answer will suffice. I'm suspecting because most people coming here fall in this category this is the most popular answer.

This answer however brings up the inherent problem that we can't compare text case insensitive until we know both texts are the same culture and we know what that culture is. This is maybe a less popular answer, but I think it is more correct and that's why I marked it as such.

What's the best way to do this with Java?

Title: Check if a variable is a String in Java. Body:

How can I determine whether a variable is a String or something else in Java?

Title: How do I get a substring of a string in Java? Body:

I want to get a new string from the third character to the end of the string, e.g. myString.substring(2). If omitting the second part means “to the end,” and if you omit the first part, does it start from the start?

Title: How do I break a string in YAML over multiple lines? Body:

I have a very long string in a YAML file:

Key: 'this is my very very very very very very long string'

I would like to express it over multiple shorter lines, e.g.,

Key: 'this is my very very very ' +
     'long string'

I want to keep quotes as above so I don’t need to escape anything inside the string. What is the correct way to do this in YAML when the file is being read from Java (e.g., using SnakeYAML)?

Title: How do I check if a string starts with a certain substring in Java? Body:

How can I check if a string starts with a certain substring in Java?

For example, I want to check if the string "Hello world" starts with "Hello".
